channel.description: Recent content in +Militant on Vishvas's notes

item.title: bAgha jatin
item.description: bAgha (tiger) jatin mukherjee, who tried to spur a revolt during WW1 with German help and die.

item.title: birsa muNDa
item.description: birsa muNDa, who threw off Christian conversion, studied rAmAyaNa and gItA, then wearing a tilaka and a yajjnopavIta, led his own hindu-tribal amalgam “Birsait” cult, fought the British and rejected the missionaries. Film.

item.title: chandrasekhara AzAd
item.description: “AzAd”, [W] pamphlet name balrAj, a brAhmaNa with a choTi shikhA, yajJNOpavIta, big biceps and a twirly moustache, who introduced himself as a boy to a mlecCha judge as “AzAd” son of “svatantra” residing in “jail”, who killed himself with the final bullet rather than surrender.

item.title: Hanuman Prasad Poddar
item.description: mArvAri in bengal, arrested and held guilty of supplying arms to revolutionary Indian Freedom fighters of Anushilan Samihiti who wanted to liberate India and waged direct war against British, shunned by his own business community, founding editor of non-profit hindu publisher gIta press, close to hindu conservatives, refused titles such as rai bhadur, knighthood, bhArata ratna and was scrupulous about discouraging attempts at praise (including destroying letters by Tilak etc.).

item.title: Harphool Jat Julaniwala
item.description: robin hood like outlaw, who killed muslim cow-butchers and closed their slaughter houses, finally betrayed to the british and hanged.

item.title: Jagabandhu Bidyadhar Mohapatra Bhramarbar Rai
item.description: the Oriya rebel against the British [wiki].

item.title: jItU (Hembram) santhAl
item.description: disciple of kAshiShvara-chakravartin, irrepressible in spirit, called the Marang Sardar or the Great Chief, defiantly conducted a Kali Puja, gathered and inspired santal-s, who restored Hindu worship at a pAla temple incorporated into the Adina mosque (now maintained by ASI), but was killed by the British. {SG}

item.title: kittUru-rANI-chennamma
item.description: who fought the British valiently, but was ultimately betrayed (KPP).

item.title: Madan Lal Dhingra
item.description: inspired by sAvarkar, assissin of a British officer, a person of strong and firm character (proved by holding his hand over a flame), whose fine speech justified it (” the killing of two millions of people every year and the outraging of our women”).

item.title: mahArAjA Fateh Bahadur Sahi
item.description: the hindu chief (accepted by mogols) of land between Ghaghara and the Gandak near gangA, who obstinately refused and harassed British overlordship. {H}

item.title: mArtANDa-varma
item.description: ruler of venAD and later travencore, who deftly overcame the piLLai rebellion and assassination attempts, annexed neighboring kingdoms, defeated the Dutch [W], modernized his army using captured Dutchmen, allied with the British, ensured that Travencore does not fall like Cochin did before Tippu.

item.title: Masterda sUrya-sena
item.description: [wiki, TW], who took on the might empire, and was brutally tortured.

item.title: pRthvI-nArAyaNa-shAha-deva of nepAla
item.description: the gUrkhAli rAjA, a mantra-sAdhaka, who beat back the British invasion, who drove out jesuit missionaries.

item.title: puli tevan
item.description: who in 1751 demanded British to quit India, fought off various muhammedan proxies and allies, was finally murdered by Yusuf Khan aka Marutanayaga [TW].

item.title: Ram Prasad Bismil
item.description: staunch Arya samAji, a fine poet in urdu (author of “sarfaroshi ki tamanna”), mentor to the hinduphilic muslim Ashfaqulla (praised in Arya samAja literature), captured and executed after looting the British occupation’s treasure in kakori. When asked for his final wishes, said: “End of British rule”, recited gAyatrI mantra.

item.title: rANI abbakka of the chauTa dynasty
item.description: the simple queen of tuLunADu, who fought the portuguese. [SW]

item.title: rAsh-bihArI-bAsu
item.description: (IMG), Plotted to assassinate the viceroy, participate in the ghaddAr movement which tried to destroy British army from inside, fled and settled in Japan, continued to help his nation from there. Masahide Bharatchandra Bose, the son of R.B. Bose, was killed in June 1945 protecting Okinawa from the US, 6 months after Bose’s death.

item.title: Shivram Hari Rajguru
item.description: who as a boy was nurtured by Ganesh Damodar aka Babarao Savarkar via the “Amravati Vyaayaam Prasaarak Mandal” gym, shot the father (by mistake) of the notorious converter Hussain Nizami leading to a cessation of such subversion in his first mission [KC17], later took part in the assassination of a British police officer, J. P. Saunders, at Lahore in 1928, executed by the British. - Far superior in comparison to his IYI accompalice the communist atheist bhagat singh.

item.title: subhASh chandra bose
item.description: a flawed urdu-islamophile, who nonetheless was a valuable agent in finally driving the british away by convincing them that the Indian army could not be relied upon to be loyal at a time when its own army wanted to disband [Ambedkar].

item.title: Subramaniya Siva Iyer
item.description: (4 October 1884 – 23 July 1925), freedom fighter who caught leprosy in prison, continued fighting till death.

item.title: tAntiya bhiil
item.description: Indian robin hood, dacoit to british and sycophants [W].

item.title: Thakur Kushal Singh Rathore
item.description: who, with some 5,000 Rajputs of Auwa rose up in arms against the British. Defeated and killed Captain Mason who came from jodhpur. Was defeated by 30,000 troops from the British governor general for Rajputana. Escaped and surrendered in 1860. Exiled to Udaipur, where he died a broken man.

item.title: vallabh bhAi paTEl
item.description: vallabh bhAi paTEl, Iron man of India, who dealt with the razAkar thugs of HyderAbAd, ensured accession of junAgarh and kAshmIr, who rebuilt sOmanAtha-shivAlaya. Among his defects: Acceeding to the wishes of MK gandhi to withdraw from prime minister candidacy in favor of javAharlAl nehru ultimately ruined the country. Mild opposition to the activities of NB Khare. nArAyaNa-bhAskara-khare As prime minister of Alwar state: achieved huge conversions in bharatpUr and AlvAr in 1947-48.

item.title: Vanchinathan Iyer
item.description: (1886 – 17 June 1911), named after वाञ्छेश्वर, inspired by Subramaniam Aiyar, he shot dead a mlecCha collector before killing himself. His letter: I dedicate my life as a small contribution to my motherland. I am alone responsible for this. The mlechas of England having captured our country, tread over the sanathana dharma of the Hindus and destroy them. Every Indian is trying to drive out the English and get swarajyam and restore sanathana dharma.

item.title: Varahaneri Venkatesa Subramaniam Aiyar
item.description: (2 April 1881 – 3 June 1925), a bhAradhvAja, inspired by VD sAvarkar sought armed resistance against the brits, operated from French puducherri, drowned trying to save his drowning daughter.

item.title: Velu Nachiyar
item.description: the princess of Ramanathapuram and the only child of Raja Chellamuthu Vijayaragunatha Sethupathy and Rani Sakandhimuthathal of the Ramnad kingdom, trained in war match weapons usage, martial arts like Valari, Silambam, horse riding and archery, proficiency with languages like French, English and Urdu; married the king of Sivagangai, with whom she had a daughter; drawn to battle after her husband, uthuvaduganathaperiyaUdaiya Thevar, was killed by British soldiers and the son of the Nawab of Arcot; escaped with her daughter; formed an army and sought an alliance with Gopala Nayaker with the aim of attacking the British; arranged a suicide attack on their ammunition depo; regained and ruled kingdom for ten more years.
